awd_titl_txt: Community for Advancing Discovery Research in Education (CADRE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project from the Community for Advancing Discovery Research in Education (CADRE) will provide assistance to Discovery Research K-12 (DRK-12) projects in national dissemination of the R&D contributions of the DRK-12 program. This project will strengthen the capacity, advance the research, and amplify the impact of DRK-12 projects and researchers working in the assessment, learning, and teaching strands. Through this effort, CADRE will advance the goals of the DRK-12 program in preK-12 formal STEM education by responding to the continuing need for communication, collaboration, and innovations among DRK-12 awardees and between awardees and the education system. The DRK-12 program seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

CADRE's goals to strengthen the capacity, advance the research, and amplify the influence of over 300 active DRK-12 projects and associated researchers are designed to contribute to improvements in preK-12 STEM education. During this project, CADRE will continue its work in three main areas: (1) supporting the DRK-12 community, (2) connecting awardees in support of knowledge generation, and (3) connecting to the larger community of education research, policy, and practice. CADRE seeks to bring together (virtually and in-person) diverse audiences to contribute to and benefit from the work of DRK-12 projects, thereby further increasing engagement in evidence-based education in the STEM disciplines. CADRE will work to ensure that the knowledge and products produced by and with DRK-12 projects are broadly accessible to a varied group of stakeholders. CADRE will disseminate the research, models, resources, and technologies--both within the program and outside--to the broader education practitioner, research, and policymaking communities. In addition, the CADRE Fellows program will support next generation of scholars and increase the capacity of a diverse group of researchers to participate in and contribute to improving education in the STEM disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
NSF invests in research and researchers to study preK-12 STEM teaching, learning, and assessment through the DRK-12 program. NSF has also invested in CADRE to support this network of researchers and the advancement of their research, as well as promote connections between communities that can translate promising DRK-12 research findings and products into STEM education improvements in schools. Education Development Center (EDC) has led CADRE for more than a decade. In this iteration, CADRE focused on broadening the future research workforce by supporting early career researchers and prospective awardees, facilitating learning experiences and dissemination opportunities for DRK-12 awardees, and developing connections between DRK-12 and the larger preK-12 STEM education community.

Select examples and outcomes from CADRE's 2018-2020 activities include the following:

  • Through the CADRE Fellows--a workforce development program for a diverse cohort of graduate students and scholars--we increased the exposure of 40 early career researchers to NSF and opportunities to network with early career peers and experienced researchers, learn about different research contexts and career tracks, and gain skills to advance their careers.
  • CADRE helped STEM education researchers build and share new knowledge, best practices, and tools critical to increasing the impact and sustainability of promising STEM education research by convening the 2021 DRK-12 PI Meeting, a conference for awardees and guests of the NSF DRK-12 program. CADRE selected and invited a group of 11 aspiring awardees from outside of the DRK-12 portfolio who represented minority-serving institutions and groups less well represented in the portfolio to attend the PI meeting. In total, 582 registrants attended, including 100 early career researchers, 45 new DRK-12 awardees, 342 first-time PI meeting attendees, and 15 NSF program officers. Select session materials and videos are available to the public on the CADREK12.org website.
  • In another effort to broaden participation in the DRK-12 portfolio, CADRE provided information for potential awardees through a proposal toolkit, updates on current DRK-12 research through monthly project Spotlights, webinars to familiarize participants with the DRK-12 solicitation and review criteria, and opportunities to attend the DRK-12 PI Meeting.
  • CADRE raised awareness about current research and supported communication and information sharing among researchers, practitioners, funders, and policymakers by disseminating information and resources through the CADREK12.org and successfulSTEMeducation.org websites,  newsletters, social media, conference presentations, and webinars. CADRE disseminated DRK-12 research syntheses and videos on a variety of topics, including early learning, broadening participation, and modeling in STEM. Syntheses have been added to teacher education curricula as far away as Australia, and the videos have been seen by more than 40,000 viewers. CADRE has also posted approximately 11,400 tweets to increase the reach of information about preK-12 STEM education.
  • We responded to the needs of the extended STEM education community during the COVID pandemic by redesigning the PI meeting as a virtual event; adapting CADRE Fellows to an all-virtual program; hosting a webinar on adapting research during the pandemic; and producing and disseminating a library of evidence-based, online preK-12 STEM learning resources.

 


Last Modified: 03/12/2022
Modified by: Catherine H Mcculloch
por.por_txt_cntn:
NSF invests in research and researchers to study preK-12 STEM teaching, learning, and assessment through the DRK-12 program. Select examples and outcomes from CADRE's 2018-2020 activities include the following:

Through the CADRE Fellows--a workforce development program for a diverse cohort of graduate students and scholars--we increased the exposure of 40 early career researchers to NSF and opportunities to network with early career peers and experienced researchers, learn about different research contexts and career tracks, and gain skills to advance their careers. 
CADRE helped STEM education researchers build and share new knowledge, best practices, and tools critical to increasing the impact and sustainability of promising STEM education research by convening the 2021 DRK-12 PI Meeting, a conference for awardees and guests of the NSF DRK-12 program. CADRE raised awareness about current research and supported communication and information sharing among researchers, practitioners, funders, and policymakers by disseminating information and resources through the CADREK12.org and successfulSTEMeducation.org websites,  newsletters, social media, conference presentations, and webinars. CADRE disseminated DRK-12 research syntheses and videos on a variety of topics, including early learning, broadening participation, and modeling in STEM. We responded to the needs of the extended STEM education community during the COVID pandemic by redesigning the PI meeting as a virtual event; adapting CADRE Fellows to an all-virtual program; hosting a webinar on adapting research during the pandemic; and producing and disseminating a library of evidence-based, online preK-12 STEM learning resources.
